results.title: Animal babies grow up
results.brief_description: Puppies and piglets, a colt and a kangaroo, opossums, woodchuck, snakes, fish, birds, tadpoles and caterpillars illustrate how animals are born, and the stages they undergo as they develop. Important life science concepts include the extent of care given by the mother, feeding habits of the young, and that while some may not look like their parents at birth, all grow up to resemble them. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: The Ancient Peruvian
results.creator_credit: James Sage, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: Explores the art, architecture, religions and society of pre-Columbian culture in Peru. Live footage intercut with animation portrays the rise and fall of these vanished people, and contrasts ancient and contemporary Peru. Music incorporates pre-Columbian harmonies based on scales obtained from tuning clay and reed flutes. Suitable for upper primary levels.

results.title: Anchor man
results.brief_description: Describes how the Royal Australian Navy trains reservists as part-time sailors. They train once a week and receive two weeks full time training at sea where they learn the skills needed to man a Defense craft. They would back up the permanent servicemen in the event of hostile action. No other credits available.

results.title: The American parade: we the women
results.brief_description: This factual treatment of the American past balances the unintentional sexism of most US history as now taught. Names like Sarah and Angelina Grimke, Lucretia Mott, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Sojourner Truth, Susan B. Anthony, and Carrie Chapman Catt will now become familiar through vivid, often humorous, sometimes deeply moving historical dramatizations. This film is an introduction to the American women’s movement. Narrated by Mary Tyler Moore. Associate Producer: Lois Bianchi.

results.title: Amazing platypus [Italian version]
results.creator_credit: John Shaw, John Morris and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The playtpus is one of nature’s shy creatures. Only twice has a playtpus bred in captivity. Because they are found only in Australia, and will not breed in zoos, most people know very little about the playtpus. This exceptional film shows the playtpus on dry land, underwater and by means of a carefully sectioned burrow , we even follow him into his home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Shaw, John Morris and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Altar masterpiece
results.brief_description: During the 15th Century the burghers of Krakow commissioned Wit Stwocz, master wood-carver and sculptor, to create a monumental altar-piece for St. Mary’s church, Krakow, the former capital of Poland. This film describes the altar-piece and its setting in medieval Krakow. It shows how the history of that period, its people, clothes and customs has been woven by Wit Stwocz into the story told in the altar’s carving.

results.title: Alpine sunshine
results.brief_description: Skiing in the Austrian Tyrol. Little villages of a few houses and hotels which are deserted in summer attract hundreds of tourists for winter sports. From the nursery slopes skiers graduate to the weekly races, full day excursions into the mountains, and long runs down from the top of the chair lift.

results.title: Almost a formal beginning
results.creator_credit: Richard Mitchell, Michael Robertson and Endeavour Production
results.brief_description: A tribute to the metal trades industry to mark its 1873-l973 centenary. Based on the concept of change, it shows the changes brought about in man’s life by the use of metal.

results.title: Allures
results.brief_description: Abstract animation by Jordan Belson. Intended to express “the subliminal rhythms of the inner cosmos”, this experimental film portrays an hallucinogenic voyage into outer space. It consists of sequences featuring interplay of dots, lines, planes, intricate kaleidoscopic designs, circles, grids, rhythms, textures, intensities and variations of focus. The images themselves often suggest the infinity of outer space or of subatomic particles, the snappy impersonality of computers or the undulation of romantic coloured clouds, provide filmed contrasts and tensions complemented by a musical soundtrack which itself acts as a counterpoint.
